qas.question: What was a known issue of using shellac to make records?
In which novel does 'Whiteman's Lady of the Evening" record get broken?

answers.text: John O'Hara novel, Appointment in Samarra

qas.question: In Blackboard Jungle what record breaking mention is made?

answers.text: teacher's collection of 78 rpm jazz records is smashed

context: <a0_0>Breakage was very common<a0_0/> in the shellac era. In the 1934 <a1_0>John O'Hara novel, Appointment in Samarra<a1_0/>, the protagonist "broke one of his most favorites, Whiteman's Lady of the Evening ... He wanted to cry but could not." A poignant moment in J. D. Salinger's 1951 novel The Catcher in the Rye occurs after the adolescent protagonist buys a record for his younger sister but drops it and "it broke into pieces ... I damn-near cried, it made me feel so terrible." A sequence where a school <a2_0>teacher's collection of 78 rpm jazz records is smashed<a2_0/> by a group of rebellious students is a key moment in the film Blackboard Jungle.
